The Marshall-Olkin distribution

Source: vignettes/The-Marshall-Olkin-distribution.Rmd
The-Marshall-Olkin-distribution.Rmd

The following document is a compendium for the Marshall–Olkin distribution.

For a detailed mathematical treatment of this class, we refer to the references at the end of this document.

Definition and survival copula

A d-variate random vector \(\boldsymbol{\tau} = (\tau_1, \ldots, \tau_d)\) has a Marshall–Olkin distribution with parameters \(\lambda_I, \ \emptyset \neq I \subseteq \{1, \ldots, d\}\) if and only if it has the multivariate survival function \[ \bar{F} (\boldsymbol{t}) = \exp \left\{ - \sum_{\emptyset \neq I \subseteq \{1, \ldots, d\}} \lambda_I \max_{i\in I} t_i \right\}, \ \boldsymbol{t} = (t_1, \ldots, t_d) \geq 0 , \] and the parameters fulfil \[ \eta_i := \sum_{I \ni i} \lambda_I > 0 \ \forall i \in \{1, \ldots, d\} . \]

Marginal survival functions

The marginal random variables \(\tau_i\) of a d-variate Marshall-Olkin distributed random vector are exponentially distributed with rates \(\eta_i, \ i \in \{1, \ldots, d\}\). In particular, this implies that \(\tau_i\) has the survival function \[ \bar{F}_i (t) = \exp \left\{ - t \eta_i \right\} = \exp \left\{ - t \sum_{I \ni i} \lambda_I \right\} , \ i \in \{1, \ldots, d\}, \ t \geq 0 . \]

Survival copula

The survival copula \(\hat{C}\) of a d-variate Marshall–Olkin distributed random vector is \[ \hat{C} (\boldsymbol{u}) = \prod_{\emptyset\neq I \subseteq [d]} \min_{i \in I} u_i^{\frac{\lambda_I}{\eta_i}}, \quad \boldsymbol{u} \in [0, 1]^d . \]

Pickands measure and function

The Marshall–Olkin distribution is Min-stable multivariate exponential (MSMVE) and has a survival copula of extreme-value kind. The Pickands measure \(\delta\) of a d-variate Marshall–Olkin distributed random vector is \[ \delta \left( \frac{ \sum_{i\in I} \vec{e}_i \prod_{i \neq j \in I} \eta_j }{ \sum_{i\in I} \prod_{i \neq j \in I} \eta_j } \right) = \lambda_I \sum_{i\in I} \frac{1}{\eta_i} , \quad \emptyset \neq I \subseteq [d] . \] The Pickands function \(P\) of a d-variate Marshall–Olkin distributed random vector is \[ P (\boldsymbol{w}) := \int_{S_d} \max_{i \in [d]} \{ w_i u_i \} \mathrm{d} \,\delta(\boldsymbol{u}) = \sum_{\emptyset\neq I \subseteq [d]} \lambda_I \max_{i \in I} \frac{w_i}{\eta_i} . \]

The exogenous shock model

A d-variate Marshall–Olkin distribution has a natural stochastic model: consider independent random variables \(E_I \sim \mathrm{Exp} (\lambda_I), \ \emptyset \neq I \subseteq \{1, \ldots, d\}\) and define \[ \tau_i := \min \Big\{ E_I \ : \ I \ni i \Big\} , \ i \in \{ 1 , \ldots , d \} . \]

The Arnold model

A d-variate Marshall–Olkin distribution has another stochastic model which is strongly linked to continuous time, homogeneous Markovian processes. For this, consider the transformed parameters \[ \lambda := \sum_{\emptyset \neq I \subseteq \{1, \ldots, d\}} \lambda_I \] and \[ p_I := \frac{\lambda_I}{\lambda}, \ \emptyset \neq I \subseteq \{ 1, \ldots, d \} . \] Then, it can be shown that the vector \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\), defined below, has the desired Marshall–Olkin distribution. Let the following two sequences be independent:

  • \(\epsilon_1, \epsilon_2, \ldots \sim \mathrm{Exp} (\lambda)\) iid.
  • \(Y_1, Y_2, \ldots\) iid in \(\mathcal{P} (\{1, \ldots, d\}) \backslash \{ 0\}\) with \(\mathbb{P} (Y_1 = I) = p_I, \ \emptyset \neq I \subseteq \{ 1, \ldots , d\}\).

Now, we define \(\boldsymbol{\tau}\) by \[ \tau_i := \sum_{j=1}^{\min \{ k \in \mathbb{N} : i \in Y_k\}} \epsilon_j , \quad i \in \{ 1, \ldots, d\} . \]

References

Mai, Jan-Frederik, and Matthias Scherer. 2010. “The Pickands Representation of Survival Marshall–Olkin Copulas.” Statistics & Probability Letters 80 (5): 357–60. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.spl.2009.11.010.

———. 2017. Simulating Copulas. 2nd ed. World Scientific. https://doi.org/10.1142/10265.
